tasks.task: Conducting field trials for evaluating furrow irrigation design parameters
subtasks: Selecting a representative segment of the furrow field
Choosing a range of stream sizes (e.g., Q_max, higher and lower values)
Measuring elapsed time for waterfront movement downstream
Plotting advance curves for different stream sizes
Determining the maximum allowable non-erosive stream size (Q_max)
Verifying Q_max using empirical data from field trials
Adjusting length of the furrow segment through iterative procedure if necessary
Evaluating distribution pattern efficiency (FAR) and adjusting parameters accordingly
Checking cutoff time and computing maximum depth of flow (D_max) for level basin design
Considering application efficiency (Ea) in designing irrigation systems
Using empirical tables for area allocation based on soil type
Defining unit stream size (Q divided by width of basin)
Calculating time of advance (Tna) using hydraulic relationships
Determining length of the level basin
Ensuring that time of advance does not exceed cutoff time for reliable infiltration
Calculating ridge size based on maximum depth of flow (D_max)
Considering distribution pattern efficiency for optimal water distribution

tasks.task: Ensuring accurate water application through trial runs and adjusting parameters
subtasks: Evaluating trial runs to check alignment with empirical data
Iteratively adjusting parameters such as furrow length or stream size to optimize water use
Verifying design parameters using observed advance times and erosion levels
Using different efficiency metrics (e.g., distribution pattern ratio) to fine-tune designs
Confirming that irrigation methods meet desired efficiency and erosion control goals
